I have seen both paradigms (asio and sd_event) when working with phosphor-health-monitor and am curious how it turns out for the watchdog.

Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)
Nevermind, seems to leak again.
Ack
Do we want to add this back somehow?

+1.  This should be using asio signal_set:
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_78_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/signal_set.html
Done
cannot call enable(value) because there will be a loop and break stuff.

This does not exactly the same as before.

The run_for() return value is the number of handler is ran during the time. It could be zero if there are no handlers that is ready.

This is a really odd pattern, and something we should avoid.  async timers should be setting callbacks, and we shouldn't be relyng on run_for in calling code.  Asio is fully capable of setting up the io_context to run for a particular amount of time, internally using the equivalent of run_for, so all we need to do in this context is set up a timer and enable an async_wait, with a callback checking for operation_aborted.

updated to use io.run() and rely on io.cancel to exit. Should be cleaner/better now.

Thanks.

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > Patch Set 7:
> > 
> > This one (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-health-monitor/+/42144/2/healthMonitor.cpp#531) ... used the sdbusplus::asio::sd_event_wrapper once.
> 
> oh, maybe I should try that instead to see maybe that's cleaner.

Tried it out and it seems like it still leaks memory or just too much memory usage in general. I have removed the sdevent and its timer to use a standalone timer instead. Seems to be doing fine for now.
Prefer io_context (which is the same typedef internally) for new code to match with the std proposals.
Done
given the whole point of this patch is to remove sd_event, I don't think this is needed?
oh yeah, thanks. I was testing ASIO wrapper for sdevent to see if it is better. (it was not).
Why are you using the base class directly now?
Need it for convertActionFromString.
convertActionFromString is available in the Watchdog object namespace, and was used previously there, so I still don't understand why you need to go directly to the base class.
The Watchdog object does be inherent WatchdogBase anymore, so it doesn't have it.
no, but there's a using Actions = WatchdogBase::Actions in the Watchdog definition......  Seems odd we wouldn't use it.

my understanding is that if we inherent WatchdogBase or `sdbusplus::xyz::openbmc_project::State::server::Watchdog`

We would need to use the following constructor
```
/** @brief Constructor to put object onto bus at a dbus path.
         *  @param[in] bus - Bus to attach to.
         *  @param[in] path - Path to attach at.
         */
        Watchdog(bus::bus& bus, const char* path);
```

which will force us to create the dbus object.

----

I couldn't use `using WatchdogBase::convertActionFromString` directly.

I have set a static function to get access to it from Watchdog now. Maybe that will work better?
Ah, I see now.  You're not using it for action.......  I'm not loving how messy it is, but I guess that works.

same. Maybe WatchdogBase::... might be better?

----

On a side note, William has https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-watchdog/+/50187 to fix the leak issue. I haven't been able to test it yet.

Should we still covert it to ASIO?

Also a patch to systemd that "fixes" it too.
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/22046#issuecomment-1007616665

Although I'm not sure why their eventfd is getting desyncd from processing.
nice
Aren't these also within the Watchdog Namespace?
moved to Watchdog::Action

We likely don't want to be managing our own loop here.  We should be managing our timers within the io_context callbacks, and simply calling run().  run_one() is going to block in weird ways that you don't expect.
yeah, I moved the `continueAfterTimeout` logic to a timeout handler in Watchdog and will get triggered once the timer timeout. It will stop the io and stuff.

Once the below removal of the done parameter is completed, I think this whole lambda registration can move into the Watchdog constructor, given that the watchdog constructor already has the io_context as the first constructor parameter, and continueAfterTimeout can be passed in as a value parameter.  I think that simplifies the code quite a bit.
Done. Cleaned it up and removed the lambdas.
Rather than declare this as a variable, does it make more sense to do this inline in the async_wait call?
Done
Rather than set this variable, then do the stop in the watchdog callback, should we just do io.stop() here, and remove the done variable entirely?
Done

You don't need two signal set objects.  Construct a single signal set with two signals

boost::asio::signal_set sigSet(io, SIGINT, SIGTERM);
Done
Given that timer is capturing and using references within this object, it should be the last thing declared, otherwise it's possible you'll get seg faults as the timer is shutting down.
oh, interesting. Make sense.
Ack
Came across this again, do we want to consider this change or nah?
